document.text: Thic April term of the circuit court of Apipmat1X county will convene here Monday at 1000 A.M. This will be the first term of the local circuit! court presided over by Judge W. Flood, recently appointed by the General Assembly to serve the unexpired term of the. late Judge Robert F. Hutcheson. A large attend ance is expected for the opening sessions Monday. The criminal docket for the term will be fairly light. Indications are that there will be only three In dictments, and that the term can be completed in two days. Judge N. S. turn bail, of Victoria, Tias been de signated 0 preside hi certain chan cery matters in which Judge Flood was an attorney prior to his eleva tion to the bench. He is expected to come here for this purpose Tues day or later Iri the session. Trial Justice L. F. Terguson .will hold court here Saturday to hear a case resulting from a recent auto mobile accident. . . -.

document.text: The October term of the circuit court of Appomattox county, with Judge Robert F. Hutcheson presid ing, will convene here Monday, at 10 A.M . The probability is that there will be only three indictments, and that the matters to come before the court can be disposed of in two days. Nevertheless the usual large attendance at court sessions here is expected. For the first time in a decade, prisoners confined in the county jail made good an escape last week-end. Three negro prisoners opened a hole in the brick wall opposite their se cond flood cells early Friday morn ing and lowered themselves down a blanket-ladder to freedom. They pried the bricks loose during the night, without awakening a fourth prisoner in the same cell. Saturday afternoon one of the ea-

CHORUS GIRLS CAN EAT AGAIN is reported to be I one of two winners in the flag contest of the schools of that city., Miss Ann has many young friends here who congratulate her on her achievement. Judge Robert F. Hutcheson, of the Circuit Court of Prince Edward County, has designate ed May 30 as a special term of court to try Ernest Pegram, colored, of the county for the alleged murder of- Frank -W. Gilliam, game warden, on Sun day, April 28_. Pegram will remain in th Henrico County jail, where he was taken soon after the murder, until the day of his trial.

document.text: Miss Ann Abbitt, the young daughter of Dr. J. B. Abbitt, of Norfolk, Va., is reported to be one of two winners in the flag contest of the schools of that city. Miss Ann has many young friends here who congratulate her on her achievement. Judge Robert F. Hutcheson, of the Circuit Court of Prince Edward COunty, has designat ed May 30 as a special term of court to try Ernest Pegram, colored, of the county for the alleged murder of. Frank -W. Gilliam, game warden, on Sun day, April 28. Pegram will remain in the Henrico County jail, where he was taken soon after the murder, until the day of his trial.

document.text: Masons Elect Officers. Eureka Mills.At a stated commu nication of St. Johns Masonic Lodge, the following officers were elected for the ensuing year Worshipful Master, Lee W. Morton C. A. Hoy, senior warden Robert F. Hutcheson, junior warden J. C. Carrington, treasurer E. E. Gibbs, secretary Thomas J. Watkins, senior deacon C. M. Hutch eson, junior deacon J. T. Dunnavant, tiler W. P. Ingram, and Gibbs Rice, stewards Revs. Leonard Cox, R. L. McNair, A. B. Sharpe and G. H. Leep- er, chaplains. J. C. Carrington, T. J. Watkins and T. Roy Adams were elected alternates to the Grand Lodge. District Deputy Grand Master W. G. Williams was recommended for reap pointment.

document.text: Ivy Holland and Lewis McDear- man attended Ruritan Club conven tion in Richmond. Farmers National Bank entertains shareholders at dinner. Professor John Smelts signed to succeed Charles A. Hilt, resigned, I on local high school faculty. Rev. O.G. Burnette accepts call to Baptist field of churches in Halt- fax county. Walton S. Tweedy, 63, died Jan uary 10th. Judge Robert F . Hutcheson died January 12th. Dr. J .J . Wicker supplied pulpit at Liberty church. Senator Chas. T . Moses attends sessions of the General Assembly in Richmond.

document.text: F. HUTCHESON R. O. Garrett Esquire presented to the court a copy of the proceedings of a public meeting of the Bar and officers of the court, and cither citi zens being present, held at Cumber land Court House on this 23rd day cf April, 1940, relative, to the death of Judge Robert F . Hutcheson, and on his motio,, and pursuant to the request of said meeting as therein set out, it is ordered that the said proceedings be spread at large upon the records of this courts which was accordingly done as follows Hon. Joel W. Flood was called to the chair and Letwis Crawley was chosen secretary. At the January Term, 1940, of this court, R. O. Garrett, E. H. G a mage, A. L. Putt, Jr., and Wm. M. Smith, were appointed a com mittee to draft suitable resolutions m memory of the Hon. Robert F . Hutcheson and after meeting of said committee the following resolutions were entered xt is appropriate and proper when a comrade has fallen from our tanka that toe survivors should take notice thereof, and_wnn reverence toward our Heavenly Father who givath and wno taketh .way, to commune together in memorial service and whereas we have now assembled to gether to pay our tribute of a.fec- tttn and honor to the name of the late Robert F . Hutcheson, Judge of the Fifth Judicial Circuit of Vir ginia, who died m January, 194Q, and to bear witness to this county of which he was the beloved Judge THEREFORE BE IT REbOLVKD Thai we declare our profound grief and sorrow boat our cherished friend and worthy judge has been cut off in the prime of life. To his strong natural mind had been added the attainmenia of liberal education, cultured associations and intelligent researches, added to a storehouse of knowledge. Be i further resolved that he was fearless, upright, accomplished, just, learned and impartial judge, of i he highest sense of integrity, The a copy of these resolutions be sent to the family of Judge Hutch eson, and copies be sent to the press for publication, and a copy be spread upon the records o f the Circuit Court of Cumberland County aad that E. Flood, Judge Copy-Teste- Lewis Crawley, Clerk.

document.text: Every person in this section of Virginia will be genuinely grieved  4 h. r of the illness of our beloved 1 circuit court Judge, Hori. Robert F. Hutcheson. Possessed of those be- letarng traits so happily associated ir.-ttb a true Virginia gentleman, our ijude is a man whose frienda are Tloeend and hen-rs theexalted office ! i g hoids. We wish for him a speedy j return to complete health.  1  . i . . . n .

document.text: Col , Joel W. Flood, of Appo mattox, has received wide endorse ment for the judicial vacancy caus ed by the death of Judge Robert. F, Hutcheson. A causcus of the Democrats in the General Assembly is scheduled to be held next Tuesday to nominate a candidate to succeed udge Hutcheson. Col. Flood has received the en dorsement and active support of the bar associations o f Appomattox, Buckingham and Cumberland coun ties, and bas been urged to become a candidate for the judgeship by friends from all parts of the State. State Senator Charles T . Moses, who is actively supporting Col. Flood, stated this week that he had been highly gratified at the pledges from mëmberS of the General Assembly to support Col. Flood and that bis nomination for the vacancy on the first ballot was very probable, R . E . Garland, of Farmville, and J . Kent Early, attorneys of Farm villeand Charlotte Court House res pectively, have also been mentioned in connection with the vacancy.Mr. Garland is 40 years of age and has been a member of the Prince Edward bar for 16 years. Mr. Early is a former commonwealths attorney of Charlotte coun and unsuccessful ly opposed State Senator Moaes for the state senate in 1934. Col. Flood has outstanding qual- ftcations fitting him for the circuit bench. He is an alumnus of Wash ington and Lee University and the U, of Virginia, and took a law course at Oxford University, London. He bagan the practice of law in 1917, and was Commonwealths Attorney

document.text: Circuit Court Judge Robert F . Hutcheson convicted Rev. Joel J. Allen Thursday of last week on charges of dog poisoning and im posed a fine of 50 and. costs, the identical penalty from which the minister appealed in. trial justice court. ffhe Commopewalth sent 49 wit nesses to the stand in support of its contention the minister set out poison to kill dogs which came upon his property. Mr. Allen, who was on the stand nearly an hour, denied that he put out poison although he admitted having killed a few which he said prowled around his home Only three other defense witnesses were called, two pt whom testified that the defendant had re turned their dogs after He had found them on his property.

document.text: Buckinghamjpt 9.- It was de cided by unanimSto vote of the Buck ingham county board of supervisors last week that a reassessment of real estate in the county was nec essary and that Judge Robert F . Hutcheson, of the circuit court, be asked to appoint land accqssors, j It is expected that this will be done during the current term of the court.

document.text: Buckingham, March 20,- Special to the Times-Vir- ginianThe criminal docket jf the Circuit Court which con vened last Tuesday with Judge Robert F. Hutcheson presiding, vas one of the smallest in re lent months. Judge Hutche- ion in directing the grand jury 2 ommendod the county upon its law-abidingness. Sweetfield Murphy, who pled not guilty to the charge of stealing and butchering a calf in the town of Dillwyn, drew one year in the state pen al institution in Richmond. W. P. Wood, another defendant in the same action, was an nounced in a Government Hos pital for inebreecy and his case was continued.  The rest of Tuesday w as taken up with civil matters, with the Receiv er of the defunct First Nation al Bank of Dillwyn getting a number of judgements against stockholders of the closed bank. Jn the afternoon Mes srs. Pitts and Boatwright rep resented the plaintiff in t h e suit- in chancery brought by Walter Howard Toney versus Margaret Fountain et als. The defendants were represented by Colonel Aubrey Strode and Julian Martin. The evidence was submitted to t h e court without having the deposi tions read. The court will ren der a decision at a later date.

document.text: Judge Robert Francis Hutcheson, 62, tof the Fifth Judicial Circuit, embracing the counties of Charlotte, Prince Edwhrdv  umbeftand, Buck ingham and Appomattebt, died, last Friday morniingiat Ihis borne at Charlotte Court House, after an Ill ness of one ntonth. Funeral services for th beloved jurist were hold Saturday afternoon at 280 at the Charlotte Court House Presbyterian church, Burial wm in the churchyard. . II  y._ Judge Hutcheson became ill Dec ember 21 during Jhe December tans of court at farmville. After treat ment at the Southaide  hospital at Farmville, he returned to Charlotte Court Houae, IThe esteemed Judge hraa born in 1878, the son of Robert F. and Mary Barkadble Hutcheson. Re gradua ted from Hampden-Sydhey College in 1898. After teaching school for several yean, ha studied law at Washington and Lee University. He began the practice of hit profession at Charlotte Court House, Be sef- , ved as a member of the Houseof Delegatee for one term, j.918-20.He was appointed judge o f the Fifth Judicial Circuit in May, 1-929, by the late Governor E. Lee Trinkle, suc ceeding the late Judge George J . Hundley.

document.text: Judge Joel W. Flood, of the Fifth judicial circuit, has entered an ord- of the circuit court of Charlotte co unty, designating Saturday, May 11 ati 11 oclock A. M. as the day and hour on which memorial exercises will be held in memory of the late Judge Robert F. Hutchesoi, who was judge of the said circuit at the 1 time of his death on January 12. j _ ______ ___ The Charlotte County Bar Asso- jelt that his regular cation has charge of the memorial at night have exercises.. document.text: Judge Hutcheson will hold an adjourned session of his court here beginning Monday the 16th. The following men have been  summoned as jurymen Civil JuryM. L. Garrett, R. A. Anderson, E. L. Smith, C. J. Harding, E. Larkin Har vey, Clayton T. Drinkard, W. The District B. Y. P. U. Ral-D. Paris, J. L. Burkey and ly will be held at Evergreen Robert L. Gilbert. Baptist Church Sunday, Dec. document.text: Drought-stricken V i r g i nia farmers will be aided from an 800,009 balance of an old fund held by the Federal gov ernment, distribution to begin aext week, it was announced by John R. Hutcheson, director of the Virginia Polytechnic In stitute extension division and member of the State Drought Relief Commission. Only farm ers who cannot obtain credit i from local sources will be per mitted to borrow from this fund, he declared. It was not stated how much of the fund would be made , available to Virginia. A heated controversy has a- fisen in Republican circles in Richmond over charges made co Federal officials in Wash ington by R. Houston Brett, Richmond attorney and secre tary of the .Republics1 Club of Virginia, that certain impor tant Republican officeholders at the Virginia capital are vio- 1 lating the civil service rules by undue political activity. Mr. Brett named Joseph P. Brady, veteran clerk of the United States District Court Postmas- er Joseph W. Stewart, Cen sus Supervisor, Cyrus W. Beale and Thomas B. Snead, referee in bankruptcy. These men de- I nied the charges. Governor John Garland Pol lard is proud enough of his Virginia ancestry not to care whether he has any Massachu setts ancestry or not. Mayor Curley, of Boston recently in vited him to attend the tercent- ary celebration next month in the Massachusetts capital, and said he was trying to trace a 1 relationship between Governor Pollard and the Pollards of the Bay State. The Governor may attend the celebration, hut he I wishes it understood that he is I a Virginian first, last and al ways and that his ancestry, Robert Pollard, settled in King William County in 1652. The Richmond Magazine, published by the Richmond Chamber 6 f C o m m e r e e, charges in a copyrighted arti cle in the September issue that the administration in Washing ton has been sending out freight rate reduction propa ganda, while Secretary of Ag riculture, Hyde, has befen mak ing it difficult for the farmers to get the benefit of rate re ductions by issuing complica ted regulations tending to nul lify the Interstate Commerce Commissions order cutting all government red tape. The magazine states that the chambers agricultural i and traffic departments have been deluged with inquiries from farmers and dealers concern ing their inability to obtain the rate reduction announced in dispatches from Washington. Robert B. Vial,. 20-year-old Hanover County farmer, is be ing held in Henrico jail on a charge of murdering Laney Jones, wealthy recluse, on the Jones plantation, Hilly Farm in Hanover County., Vial is said by the authorities to have confessed to the killing of Jones, following an argument over repairs to a farm motor truck. Jones body was found sprawled on the floor of his home by a negro worker on the place. Bucket shops are run all over the State under the guise of stock exchanges, it was charged last week by Charles C. Berkeley, of Newport News, who ran for Attorney-General of Virginia on the Republican- antiSmith coalition ticket in 1929, and was defeated over whelmingly. The charge was made in a letter to Governor Pollard, who made the letter public without comment. Farmers, fruit growers and stockmen of Loudoun County, one of the richest agricultural counties in the State, are esti mated to have lost 3,000,000 as a result of the drought, ac cording to County Agent, J. R. Lightner. This total does not include deflation of prices on beef cattle, curtailment of the apple crop, or decreased milk production. A permanent Marker is ex pected to be placed on the spot in Powhatan County where General Robt. E. Lee pitched his tent for the last time. He was returning from Appomat tox to Richmond following the surrender when he camped one night several miles north of Powhatan Courthouse. The
